API Reference¶

Module simulation¶

biosim.simulation defines the BioSim class interface for simulation of Rossumøya’s ecosystem.

class biosim.simulation.BioSim(island_map, ini_pop, seed, ymax_animals=None, cmax_animals=None, img_base=None, img_fmt='png')[source]¶

This class generates the outline for the simulation of Rossumøya’s ecosystem, with visualisation.

Attributes
animal_distribution

Pandas DataFrame with animal count per species for each cell on island.

num_animals

Total number of animals on island.

num_animals_per_species

Number of animals per species in island, as dictionary.

year

Last year simulated.

Methods

add_population(self, population)

Add a population to the island

make_movie(self, movie_fmt)

Create MPEG4 movie from visualization images saved.

plot_heatmap(self)

Plots the herbivore and carnivore distribution as heatmaps.

plot_island_map(self)

Creates a map plot of the input island map string.

plot_population_graph(self)

Plots the total herbivore and carnivore population for a given year.

save_graphics(self)

Saves the images.

set_animal_parameters(self, species, params)

Set parameters for animal species.

set_landscape_parameters(self, landscape, params)

Set parameters for landscape type.

setup_graphics(self)

Creates the subplots needed for the final plot.

simulate(self, num_years[, vis_years, img_years])

Run simulation while visualizing the result.

update_graphics(self)

Updates the images.
Parameters

  • island_map – Multi-line string specifying island geography

  • ini_pop – List of dictionaries specifying initial population

  • seed – Integer used as random number seed

  • ymax_animals – Number specifying y-axis limit for graph showing

animal numbers :param cmax_animals: Dict specifying color-code limits for animal densities :param img_base: String with beginning of file name for figures, including path :param img_fmt: String with file type for figures, e.g. ‘png’

If ymax_animals is None, the y-axis limit should be adjusted automatically.

If cmax_animals is None, sensible, fixed default values should be used. cmax_animals is a dict mapping species names to numbers, e.g.,

{‘Herbivore’: 50, ‘Carnivore’: 20}

If img_base is None, no figures are written to file. Filenames are formed as

‘{}_{:05d}.{}’.format(img_base, img_no, img_fmt)

where img_no are consecutive image numbers starting from 0. img_base should contain a path and beginning of a file name.

Attributes
animal_distribution

Pandas DataFrame with animal count per species for each cell on island.

num_animals

Total number of animals on island.

num_animals_per_species

Number of animals per species in island, as dictionary.

year

Last year simulated.

set_animal_parameters(self, species, params)[source]¶

Set parameters for animal species.

Parameters

  • species – String, name of animal species

  • params – Dict with valid parameter specification for species

set_landscape_parameters(self, landscape, params)[source]¶

Set parameters for landscape type.

Parameters

  • landscape – String, code letter for landscape

  • params – Dict with valid parameter specification for landscape

setup_graphics(self)[source]¶

Creates the subplots needed for the final plot.

simulate(self, num_years, vis_years=1, img_years=None)[source]¶

Run simulation while visualizing the result.

Parameters

  • num_years – number of years to simulate

  • vis_years – years between visualization updates

  • img_years – years between visualizations saved to files

(default: vis_years)

Image files will be numbered consecutively.

update_graphics(self)[source]¶

Updates the images.

property year¶

Last year simulated.

Module island¶

biosim.island defines an island, populates the island and defines the annual cycle.

The user can define:

  • The island map.

class biosim.island.Island(island_map=None)[source]¶

This class generates the island Rossumøya and its ecosystem behaviour.

Attributes
population_in_each_cell

This method calculates the herbivore and carnivore population for each cell.

total_island_population

Finds the total number of animals on the island.

total_species_population

Finds the total number of herbivores and carnivores on the island, in the first and second element of the returned tuple, respectively.

Methods

annual_cycle(self)

This method carries out one cycle on the island.

find_cell_position(self, cell)

Finds the numpy map coordinates of the cell.

find_surrounding_cells(self, position)

Collects a cell’s neighbouring landscape types, i.e.

landscape_position_in_map(self)

Creates a numpy array map from the string map.

populate_the_island(self[, start_population])

Populates the island with an input start population.

validate_map_string(self)

Validates that a the input map string follows the constraints of the model.

This method creates variables needed for the class.

annual_cycle(self)[source]¶

This method carries out one cycle on the island.

Return total_species_population

tuple, first element is herbivore population and second element is carnivore population.

find_cell_position(self, cell)[source]¶

Finds the numpy map coordinates of the cell.

Parameters

cell – a landscape object in the numpy map.

Return position

tuple (cell coordinates).

find_surrounding_cells(self, position)[source]¶

Collects a cell’s neighbouring landscape types, i.e. the set \(C^{(i)}\).

Parameters

position – tuple (cell coordinates).

Return neighbour_cells

list, objects of adjacent cells.

Creates a numpy array map from the string map.

Populates the island with an input start population.

Parameters

start_population – list, lists of dictionaries with keys “loc” (location) and “pop” (population).

property population_in_each_cell¶

This method calculates the herbivore and carnivore population for each cell.

Returns

numpy.ndarray, the herbivore and carnivore population in the first and second element of each list, respectively.

property total_island_population¶

Finds the total number of animals on the island.

Returns

int

property total_species_population¶

Finds the total number of herbivores and carnivores on the island, in the first and second element of the returned tuple, respectively.

Returns

tuple.

validate_map_string(self)[source]¶

Validates that a the input map string follows the constraints of the model.

Module landscape¶

biosim.landscape defines how a landscape object should behave and how its animal population interact with each other and their surroundings. The subclasses, Jungle, Savannah, Desert, Mountain and Ocean, contains information about the differences between each landscape type, e.g. availability and regeneration of fodder.

class biosim.landscape.Desert[source]¶

Defines the desert type.

Attributes

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for carnivore.

available_fodder_herbivore

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for herbivore, which is

sum_of_herbivore_mass

Calculates the total herbivore mass in the specific cell, i.e.

Methods

aging(self)

The age of all animals in the specific cell is incremented by one, once a year.

cell_population(self[, population])

Puts the animal population in the specific cell.

choose_migration_cell(self, animal, …)

A method to choose which of the adjacent cell the animal should migrate to, given that it migrates, and moves the animal to that cell.

death(self)

Updates the animal population list with the surviving animals after every year.

directional_probability(self, animal, …)

This method estimates the propensity for each neighbouring cell, and calculates the probability of herbivores migrating to that cell.

eat_request_carnivore(self)

Carnivore eats after request.

eat_request_herbivore(self)

Herbivores eats after request and update of available fodder.

migrate(self, neighbour_cells)

A method that migrates all animals in a cell iteratively.

propensity(self)

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating.

reproduction(self)

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

set_landscape_parameters(new_parameters)

This method allows for manual setting of landscape parameters, i.e.

sort_by_fitness(self)

Updates and sorts animals in a specific cell by fitness, in descending order.

update_cell_population(self)

Updates the animal population in the specific cell.

weight_loss(self)

Reduces weight of all animals once a year.

This method creates variables needed for the class.

aging(self)¶

The age of all animals in the specific cell is incremented by one, once a year.

property available_fodder_carnivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for carnivore.

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of carnivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each carnivore. “Relevant fodder” is the total weight of all herbivores in cell \(k\).

Returns

float.

property available_fodder_herbivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for herbivore, which is defined as

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of herbivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each herbivore. “Relevant fodder” is the amount of plant fodder available.

Returns

float.

cell_population(self, population=None)¶

Puts the animal population in the specific cell.

Parameters

population – list.

choose_migration_cell(self, animal, neighbour_cells, probability_list)¶

A method to choose which of the adjacent cell the animal should migrate to, given that it migrates, and moves the animal to that cell.

Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • probability_list – list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

  • neighbour_cells – list, objects of adjacent cells.

death(self)¶

Updates the animal population list with the surviving animals after every year.

directional_probability(self, animal, neighbour_cells)¶

This method estimates the propensity for each neighbouring cell, and calculates the probability of herbivores migrating to that cell. Stores the result in a list.

The propensity-dependent probability is calculated according to the equation

\[p_{i \rightarrow j} = \frac{\pi_{i \rightarrow j}} {\sum_{j \in C^{(i)}} \pi_{i \rightarrow j}}\]
Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • neighbour_cells – list, the four adjacent cells.

Return probability_list

list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

eat_request_carnivore(self)¶

Carnivore eats after request.

eat_request_herbivore(self)¶

Herbivores eats after request and update of available fodder.

migrate(self, neighbour_cells)¶

A method that migrates all animals in a cell iteratively.

Parameters

neighbour_cells – list, objects of adjacent cells.

property number_of_carnivores¶

Finds the total number of carnivores in a specific cell.

Returns

integer, number of carnivores.

property number_of_herbivores¶

Finds the total number of herbivores in a specific cell.

Returns

integer, number of herbivores.

propensity(self)¶

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating. The propensity to move from \(i\) to \(j \in C^{(i)}\), i.e. from current cell to one of it’s neighbouring cells in set \(C^{(i)}\), is given by the equation

\[\pi_{i \rightarrow j} = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, \text{ if } j \text{ is Mountain or Ocean} \atop e^{\lambda \epsilon_{j}}, \text{ otherwise } }\]
Returns

tuple, the propensities of herbivore and carnivore migration in first and second element of the tuple, respectively.

reproduction(self)¶

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

classmethod set_landscape_parameters(new_parameters)¶

This method allows for manual setting of landscape parameters, i.e. to change parameter values from default values to desired values.

Parameters

new_parameters – dict, dictionary with the new parameter values. Only keys from the default parameter value dict are valid.

sort_by_fitness(self)¶

Updates and sorts animals in a specific cell by fitness, in descending order.

property sum_of_herbivore_mass¶

Calculates the total herbivore mass in the specific cell, i.e. the sum of the herbivore weights.

Returns

integer, the sum of herbivore mass in the cell.

update_cell_population(self)¶

Updates the animal population in the specific cell.

weight_loss(self)¶

Reduces weight of all animals once a year.

aging(self)¶

The age of all animals in the specific cell is incremented by one, once a year.

property available_fodder_carnivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for carnivore.

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of carnivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each carnivore. “Relevant fodder” is the total weight of all herbivores in cell \(k\).

Returns

float.

property available_fodder_herbivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for herbivore, which is defined as

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of herbivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each herbivore. “Relevant fodder” is the amount of plant fodder available.

Returns

float.

This method estimates the propensity for each neighbouring cell, and calculates the probability of herbivores migrating to that cell. Stores the result in a list.

\[p_{i \rightarrow j} = \frac{\pi_{i \rightarrow j}} {\sum_{j \in C^{(i)}} \pi_{i \rightarrow j}}\]
Parameters

  • neighbour_cells – list, the four adjacent cells.

Return probability_list

list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

propensity(self)¶

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating. The propensity to move from \(i\) to \(j \in C^{(i)}\), i.e. from current cell to one of it’s neighbouring cells in set \(C^{(i)}\), is given by the equation

\[\pi_{i \rightarrow j} = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, \text{ if } j \text{ is Mountain or Ocean} \atop e^{\lambda \epsilon_{j}}, \text{ otherwise } }\]
Returns

tuple, the propensities of herbivore and carnivore migration in first and second element of the tuple, respectively.

regenerate(self)[source]¶

This method regenerates the amount of fodder in each jungle-cell according to the equation

\[f_{ij} \gets f_{max}^{Jungle}\]
reproduction(self)¶

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

weight_loss(self)¶

A method that migrates all animals in a cell iteratively.

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating.

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

aging(self)[source]¶

The age of all animals in the specific cell is incremented by one, once a year.

property available_fodder_carnivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for carnivore.

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of carnivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each carnivore. “Relevant fodder” is the total weight of all herbivores in cell \(k\).

Returns

float.

property available_fodder_herbivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for herbivore, which is defined as

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of herbivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each herbivore. “Relevant fodder” is the amount of plant fodder available.

Returns

float.

cell_population(self, population=None)[source]¶

Puts the animal population in the specific cell.

Parameters

population – list.

choose_migration_cell(self, animal, neighbour_cells, probability_list)[source]¶

A method to choose which of the adjacent cell the animal should migrate to, given that it migrates, and moves the animal to that cell.

Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • probability_list – list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

  • neighbour_cells – list, objects of adjacent cells.

death(self)[source]¶

Updates the animal population list with the surviving animals after every year.

directional_probability(self, animal, neighbour_cells)[source]¶

This method estimates the propensity for each neighbouring cell, and calculates the probability of herbivores migrating to that cell. Stores the result in a list.

The propensity-dependent probability is calculated according to the equation

\[p_{i \rightarrow j} = \frac{\pi_{i \rightarrow j}} {\sum_{j \in C^{(i)}} \pi_{i \rightarrow j}}\]
Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • neighbour_cells – list, the four adjacent cells.

Return probability_list

list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

eat_request_carnivore(self)[source]¶

Carnivore eats after request.

eat_request_herbivore(self)[source]¶

Herbivores eats after request and update of available fodder.

migrate(self, neighbour_cells)[source]¶

A method that migrates all animals in a cell iteratively.

Parameters

neighbour_cells – list, objects of adjacent cells.

property number_of_carnivores¶

Finds the total number of carnivores in a specific cell.

Returns

integer, number of carnivores.

property number_of_herbivores¶

Finds the total number of herbivores in a specific cell.

Returns

integer, number of herbivores.

propensity(self)[source]¶

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating. The propensity to move from \(i\) to \(j \in C^{(i)}\), i.e. from current cell to one of it’s neighbouring cells in set \(C^{(i)}\), is given by the equation

\[\pi_{i \rightarrow j} = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, \text{ if } j \text{ is Mountain or Ocean} \atop e^{\lambda \epsilon_{j}}, \text{ otherwise } }\]
Returns

tuple, the propensities of herbivore and carnivore migration in first and second element of the tuple, respectively.

reproduction(self)[source]¶

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

classmethod set_landscape_parameters(new_parameters)[source]¶

This method allows for manual setting of landscape parameters, i.e. to change parameter values from default values to desired values.

Parameters

new_parameters – dict, dictionary with the new parameter values. Only keys from the default parameter value dict are valid.

sort_by_fitness(self)[source]¶

Updates and sorts animals in a specific cell by fitness, in descending order.

property sum_of_herbivore_mass¶

Calculates the total herbivore mass in the specific cell, i.e. the sum of the herbivore weights.

Returns

integer, the sum of herbivore mass in the cell.

update_cell_population(self)[source]¶

Updates the animal population in the specific cell.

weight_loss(self)[source]¶

Reduces weight of all animals once a year.

aging(self)¶

The age of all animals in the specific cell is incremented by one, once a year.

property available_fodder_carnivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for carnivore.

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of carnivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each carnivore. “Relevant fodder” is the total weight of all herbivores in cell \(k\).

Returns

float.

property available_fodder_herbivore¶

Finding the relative abundance of fodder for herbivore, which is defined as

\[\epsilon_{k} = \frac{f_{k}}{(n_{k} + 1)F'},\]

where \(f_{k}\) is the amount of relevant fodder available in cell \(k\), \(n_{k}\) is the is the number of herbivores in cell \(k\) and \(F\) the “appetite” of each herbivore. “Relevant fodder” is the amount of plant fodder available.

Returns

float.

cell_population(self, population=None)¶

Puts the animal population in the specific cell.

Parameters

population – list.

choose_migration_cell(self, animal, neighbour_cells, probability_list)¶

A method to choose which of the adjacent cell the animal should migrate to, given that it migrates, and moves the animal to that cell.

Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • probability_list – list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

  • neighbour_cells – list, objects of adjacent cells.

death(self)¶

Updates the animal population list with the surviving animals after every year.

directional_probability(self, animal, neighbour_cells)¶

This method estimates the propensity for each neighbouring cell, and calculates the probability of herbivores migrating to that cell. Stores the result in a list.

The propensity-dependent probability is calculated according to the equation

\[p_{i \rightarrow j} = \frac{\pi_{i \rightarrow j}} {\sum_{j \in C^{(i)}} \pi_{i \rightarrow j}}\]
Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • neighbour_cells – list, the four adjacent cells.

Return probability_list

list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

eat_request_herbivore(self)¶

Herbivores eats after request and update of available fodder.

property number_of_herbivores¶

Finds the total number of herbivores in a specific cell.

integer, number of herbivores.

propensity(self)¶

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating. The propensity to move from \(i\) to \(j \in C^{(i)}\), i.e. from current cell to one of it’s neighbouring cells in set \(C^{(i)}\), is given by the equation

\[\pi_{i \rightarrow j} = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, \text{ if } j \text{ is Mountain or Ocean} \atop e^{\lambda \epsilon_{j}}, \text{ otherwise } }\]
Returns

tuple, the propensities of herbivore and carnivore migration in first and second element of the tuple, respectively.

reproduction(self)¶

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

directional_probability(self, animal, neighbour_cells)¶

This method estimates the propensity for each neighbouring cell, and calculates the probability of herbivores migrating to that cell. Stores the result in a list.

The propensity-dependent probability is calculated according to the equation

\[p_{i \rightarrow j} = \frac{\pi_{i \rightarrow j}} {\sum_{j \in C^{(i)}} \pi_{i \rightarrow j}}\]
Parameters

  • animal – object, either herbivore or carnivore.

  • neighbour_cells – list, the four adjacent cells.

Return probability_list

list, probabilities of moving to an adjacent cell.

eat_request_carnivore(self)¶

Carnivore eats after request.

eat_request_herbivore(self)¶

Herbivores eats after request and update of available fodder.

migrate(self, neighbour_cells)¶

A method that migrates all animals in a cell iteratively.

Parameters

neighbour_cells – list, objects of adjacent cells.

property number_of_carnivores¶

Finds the total number of carnivores in a specific cell.

Returns

integer, number of carnivores.

property number_of_herbivores¶

Finds the total number of herbivores in a specific cell.

Returns

integer, number of herbivores.

propensity(self)¶

Calculates the propensity of an animal migrating. The propensity to move from \(i\) to \(j \in C^{(i)}\), i.e. from current cell to one of it’s neighbouring cells in set \(C^{(i)}\), is given by the equation

\[\pi_{i \rightarrow j} = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, \text{ if } j \text{ is Mountain or Ocean} \atop e^{\lambda \epsilon_{j}}, \text{ otherwise } }\]
Returns

tuple, the propensities of herbivore and carnivore migration in first and second element of the tuple, respectively.

regenerate(self)[source]¶

This method regenerates the amount of fodder in each savannah-cell according to the equation

\[f_{ij} \gets f_{ij} + \alpha \times (f_{max}^{Sav} - f_{ij}),\]

where \(\alpha\) is a parameter value for the savannah landscape type

reproduction(self)¶

Finds out which animals for each species that reproduce, based on reproduction probability, and adds a newborn of that species to the cell.

classmethod set_landscape_parameters(new_parameters)¶

This method allows for manual setting of landscape parameters, i.e. to change parameter values from default values to desired values.

Parameters

new_parameters – dict, dictionary with the new parameter values. Only keys from the default parameter value dict are valid.

sort_by_fitness(self)¶

Updates and sorts animals in a specific cell by fitness, in descending order.

property sum_of_herbivore_mass¶

Calculates the total herbivore mass in the specific cell, i.e. the sum of the herbivore weights.

Returns

integer, the sum of herbivore mass in the cell.

update_cell_population(self)¶

Updates the animal population in the specific cell.

weight_loss(self)¶

Reduces weight of all animals once a year.

Module animals¶

biosim.animals defines the similar traits between our two animals in the ecosystem. The two subclasses, Herbivore and Carnivore, specifies the more specific traits that are intrinsic for each animal. The module returns either herbivore or carnivore objects, depending on what the simulation is calling for.

The user can define:

  • The user can define the species of the animal.

  • The weight and age can be specified.

aging(self)[source]¶

Animal ages by one year.

animal_weight_loss(self)[source]¶

Updates animal weight after annual weight loss with a decrease rate of \(\eta w\), where \(\eta\) is a parameter value for the animal, and \(w\) is the animal’s current weight.

death(self)[source]¶

Estimates the probability of an animal dying, given by the equation

\[\omega(1-\phi)\]
Returns

bool.

property fitness¶

Calculates the fitness of the animal, given by the equation

\[\Phi = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, {w ≤ 0} \atop q^{+}(a, a_{\frac{1}{2}}, \phi_{age}) \times q^{-}(w, w_{\frac {1}{2}}, \phi_{weight}), \text{ else } }\]

where

\[q^{\pm}(x, x_{\frac{1}{2}}, \phi) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{\pm \phi(x - x_{\frac{1}{2}})}}\]
Returns

float.

migration_probability(self)[source]¶

Probability for the animal to migrate. The probability is calculated as \(\mu \Phi\).

Returns

bool.

reproduction_probability(self, n_animals)[source]¶

Estimates the probability of reproduction for the given animal according to the equation

\[min(1, \gamma \times \phi \times (N-1),\]

where \(N\) is the number of conspecific animals at the start of the breeding season, and \(\gamma\) and \(\phi\) are species-specific parameter values. This means that the reproduction probability is 0 if there is only one individual of a species in the given cell.

Furthermore, the probability is also 0 if the weight is

\[w < \zeta (w_{birth} + \sigma_{birth}),\]

where \(\zeta, w_{birth}\) and \(\sigma_{birth}\) are all species-specific parameter values.

Parameters

n_animals – integer, number of animals that may reproduce.

Return reproduction_success

bool, the animal reproduces or not.

classmethod set_animal_parameters(new_parameters)[source]¶

This method allows for manual setting of animal parameters, i.e. to change parameter values from default values to desired values.

The parameters \(w_{birth},\sigma_{birth}, \beta, \eta, a_\frac{1}{2}, \phi_{age}, w_\frac{1}{2}, \phi_{weight}, \mu, \lambda, \gamma, \zeta, \xi, \omega, F\) and \(\Delta\Phi_{max}\) are identical for all animals of the same species, but may be different between herbivores and carnivores.

Parameters

new_parameters – dict, dictionary with the new parameter values. Only keys from the default parameter value dict are valid.

update_weight_after_birth(self)[source]¶

If reproduction is successful a new animal is born, and the mother’s weight is reduced by the equation

\[w = \xi * N(w_{birth}, \sigma_{birth}),\]

where \(N(w_{birth}, \sigma_{birth})\) is the newborn’s weight that is normally distributed with mean \(w_{birth}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma_{birth}\), and \(\xi\) is a parameter value for the animal.

aging(self)¶

Animal ages by one year.

animal_weight_loss(self)¶

Updates animal weight after annual weight loss with a decrease rate of \(\eta w\), where \(\eta\) is a parameter value for the animal, and \(w\) is the animal’s current weight.

death(self)¶

Estimates the probability of an animal dying, given by the equation

\[\omega(1-\phi)\]
Returns

bool.

eating(self, herbivores)[source]¶

Calculates the new weight of the carnivore after eating fodder. The carnivores weight increases by \(\beta w_{herb}\), where \(w_{herb}\) is the weight of the herbivore killed, or the weight amount of the herbivore that the carnivore eats to become satiated.

Parameters

herbivores – float, amount of fodder eaten by the herbivore.

Return herbivores_not_eaten

list of surviving herbivores.

eating_probability(self, herbivores)[source]¶

Estimates the probability of a carnivore to eat a herbivore. Carnivores kill herbivores with probability

\[p = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, \text{ if } {\Phi_{carn} ≤ \Phi_{herb}} \atop \frac{\Phi_{carn} - \Phi_{herb}}{\Delta\Phi_{max}}, \text{ if } {0 < \Phi_{carn} - \Phi_{herb} < \Delta\Phi_{max}} }\]

If neither of these conditions occur, the probability is 1.

Parameters

herbivores – list of herbivores.

Returns

float, probability of eating.

property fitness¶

Calculates the fitness of the animal, given by the equation

\[\Phi = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, {w ≤ 0} \atop q^{+}(a, a_{\frac{1}{2}}, \phi_{age}) \times q^{-}(w, w_{\frac {1}{2}}, \phi_{weight}), \text{ else } }\]

where

\[q^{\pm}(x, x_{\frac{1}{2}}, \phi) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{\pm \phi(x - x_{\frac{1}{2}})}}\]
Returns

float.

migration_probability(self)¶

Probability for the animal to migrate. The probability is calculated as \(\mu \Phi\).

Returns

bool.

move(self, cell)[source]¶

This method appends the carnivore to a list of the new population of the cell.

Parameters

cell – object, landscape type of the position in map.

reproduction_probability(self, n_animals)¶

Estimates the probability of reproduction for the given animal according to the equation

\[min(1, \gamma \times \phi \times (N-1),\]

where \(N\) is the number of conspecific animals at the start of the breeding season, and \(\gamma\) and \(\phi\) are species-specific parameter values. This means that the reproduction probability is 0 if there is only one individual of a species in the given cell.

Furthermore, the probability is also 0 if the weight is

\[w < \zeta (w_{birth} + \sigma_{birth}),\]

where \(\zeta, w_{birth}\) and \(\sigma_{birth}\) are all species-specific parameter values.

Parameters

n_animals – integer, number of animals that may reproduce.

Return reproduction_success

bool, the animal reproduces or not.

This method allows for manual setting of animal parameters, i.e. to change parameter values from default values to desired values.

update_weight_after_birth(self)¶

If reproduction is successful a new animal is born, and the mother’s weight is reduced by the equation

\[w = \xi * N(w_{birth}, \sigma_{birth}),\]

where \(N(w_{birth}, \sigma_{birth})\) is the newborn’s weight that is normally distributed with mean \(w_{birth}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma_{birth}\), and \(\xi\) is a parameter value for the animal.

aging(self)¶

Animal ages by one year.

animal_weight_loss(self)¶

Updates animal weight after annual weight loss with a decrease rate of \(\eta w\), where \(\eta\) is a parameter value for the animal, and \(w\) is the animal’s current weight.

death(self)¶

Estimates the probability of an animal dying, given by the equation

\[\omega(1-\phi)\]
Returns

bool.

eating(self, fodder)[source]¶

Calculates the new weight of the herbivore after eating fodder. Given that a herbivore eats an amount \(\tilde{F}\) of fodder, it’s weight increases by \(\beta \tilde{F}\), where \(\beta\) is a parameter value specific for herbivores.

Parameters

fodder – float, amount of fodder eaten by the herbivore.

property fitness¶

Calculates the fitness of the animal, given by the equation

\[\Phi = \Biggl \lbrace { 0, {w ≤ 0} \atop q^{+}(a, a_{\frac{1}{2}}, \phi_{age}) \times q^{-}(w, w_{\frac {1}{2}}, \phi_{weight}), \text{ else } }\]

where

\[q^{\pm}(x, x_{\frac{1}{2}}, \phi) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{\pm \phi(x - x_{\frac{1}{2}})}}\]
Returns

float.

migration_probability(self)¶

Probability for the animal to migrate. The probability is calculated as \(\mu \Phi\).

Returns

bool.

move(self, cell)[source]¶

This method appends the herbivore to a list of the new population of the cell.

Parameters

reproduction_probability(self, n_animals)¶

Estimates the probability of reproduction for the given animal according to the equation

\[min(1, \gamma \times \phi \times (N-1),\]

where \(N\) is the number of conspecific animals at the start of the breeding season, and \(\gamma\) and \(\phi\) are species-specific parameter values. This means that the reproduction probability is 0 if there is only one individual of a species in the given cell.

Furthermore, the probability is also 0 if the weight is

\[w < \zeta (w_{birth} + \sigma_{birth}),\]

where \(\zeta, w_{birth}\) and \(\sigma_{birth}\) are all species-specific parameter values.

Parameters

n_animals – integer, number of animals that may reproduce.

Return reproduction_success

bool, the animal reproduces or not.

classmethod set_animal_parameters(new_parameters)¶

This method allows for manual setting of animal parameters, i.e. to change parameter values from default values to desired values.

The parameters \(w_{birth},\sigma_{birth}, \beta, \eta, a_\frac{1}{2}, \phi_{age}, w_\frac{1}{2}, \phi_{weight}, \mu, \lambda, \gamma, \zeta, \xi, \omega, F\) and \(\Delta\Phi_{max}\) are identical for all animals of the same species, but may be different between herbivores and carnivores.

Parameters

new_parameters – dict, dictionary with the new parameter values. Only keys from the default parameter value dict are valid.

update_weight_after_birth(self)¶

If reproduction is successful a new animal is born, and the mother’s weight is reduced by the equation

\[w = \xi * N(w_{birth}, \sigma_{birth}),\]

where \(N(w_{birth}, \sigma_{birth})\) is the newborn’s weight that is normally distributed with mean \(w_{birth}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma_{birth}\), and \(\xi\) is a parameter value for the animal.
